subject: linear_algebra
title: Elementary Row Operations
contentHtml:
Elementary row operations are a fundamental concept in linear algebra that allows us to transform systems of linear equations into equivalent forms.

These operations involve adding a multiple of one row to another, swapping two rows, or multiplying all entries in a row by a non-zero scalar.
latex: \\[\\begin{array}{c} \\text{Add }k\\text{ times the }i^{th}\\text{ row to the }j^{th}\\text{ row: }A_{ij}+kA_{ii}=A_{ij} \\\\ \\text{Swap rows }i\\text{ and }j:\\ A_{ij} \\leftrightarrow A_{ji} \\\\ \\text{Multiply row }i\\text{ by scalar }c:\\ cA_{i}\\end{array}\] \\[",
name: Row Operations" },
intuition: Think of elementary row operations as a way to 'rearrange' the rows of a matrix without changing its underlying structure. This allows us to simplify or solve systems of linear equations more easily.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, elementary row operations are used in algorithms like Gaussian elimination and LU decomposition to solve systems of linear equations.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Elementary Row Operations
contentHtml:
When solving systems of linear equations, we often need to manipulate the augmented matrix to put it in a more convenient form. This is where elementary row operations come in â€“ three types of operations that allow us to transform one row-equivalent matrix into another.

The three types of elementary row operations are:

  • Swap two rows,
  • Multiply a row by a non-zero scalar,
  • Add a multiple of one row to another.
intuition: Elementary row operations are like a set of 'get out of jail free' cards for linear algebra. They allow us to manipulate the matrix in ways that preserve its solvability, making it easier to find solutions.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, elementary row operations can be used to preprocess data before applying dimensionality reduction techniques.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse elementary row operations with more advanced transformations like Gaussian elimination.

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml:
Consider the system of linear equations:
\[x + 2y - z = 1\]
\[3x - y + 4z = 0\]
\[-x + 3y + 2z = -1\]. Perform elementary row operations to transform it into an upper triangular matrix.",
hints: Start by swapping the second and third rows.
Add a multiple of the first row to the second row to eliminate the x term.
Swap the second and third rows again.
solutionHtml:
To start, we swap the second and third rows:
\[x + 2y - z = 1\]
\[-x + 3y + 2z = -1\]
\[3x - y + 4z = 0\]. Then, we add -3 times the first row to the second row to eliminate the x term:
\[x + 2y - z = 1\]
\[-4x + 5y + 2z = -3\]
\[3x - y + 4z = 0\]. Finally, we swap the second and third rows again to get:
\[x + 2y - z = 1\]
\[3x - y + 4z = 0\]
\[-4x + 5y + 2z = -3\].",

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Given a system of linear equations Ax = b, perform elementary row operations to transform it into row-echelon form.
hints: Start by swapping rows if necessary.
Use row multiplication and addition to make the first non-zero entry in each row equal to 1.
Repeat this process until you reach the augmented matrix.
solutionHtml:
Let's say we have the system:

\[\begin{align*} 2x_1 + x_2 &= 3, \\ x_1 - 2x_2 &= -1. \end{align*}\]

We can perform elementary row operations to get:

\[\begin{align*} 1x_1 + \frac{1}{2}x_2 &= \frac{3}{2}, \\ x_1 - 4x_2 &= -5. \end{align*}\]",

\[2x - y + 3z = 1\]

\[-x + 4y + 2z = -5\]

",

\[x + 2y - z = 3\]

\[R_1 \to R_1 + 2R_2: x + 4y - 2z = 7\]

\[R_2 \to R_2 - 2R_1: 0 = y - z = 1\]

\[R_3 \to R_3 + 2R_2: -x + 6y + 4z = -5\]

\[R_2 \to R_2 - R_3: 0 = y - 3/2z = 1/2\]
